title: 112_s170
content: The Act titled "Helping Responsible Homeowners Act" allows for affordable refinancing of mortgages owned or guaranteed by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The "Helping Responsible Homeowners Act" defines key terms such as Director, Enterprise, and Qualified mortgage, which are essential for the affordable refinancing of mortgages owned or guaranteed by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The "Helping Responsible Homeowners Act" defines a qualified mortgage as an existing first mortgage on a one to four-family dwelling, owned or guaranteed by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac, and occupied by the mortgagor as their principal residence. The "Helping Responsible Homeowners Act" defines a qualified mortgage as a first mortgage on a dwelling owned or guaranteed by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac, occupied by the mortgagor as their principal residence, and the mortgagor is current on payments. A refinancing mortgage is a mortgage that meets specific requirements. A refinancing mortgage is a mortgage used to pay off all debt under an existing qualified mortgage and any closing costs included in the refinanced mortgage. The principal loan amount secured by the mortgage is used to pay off existing debt and closing costs in the refinanced mortgage. The property subject to the mortgage must be the same as the qualified mortgage being refinanced, and the mortgage must have a fair interest rate not exceeding 40 basis points. The mortgage for single-family housing must be on the same property as the qualified mortgage being refinanced and have a fair interest rate not exceeding 40 basis points above the required net yield. The mortgage for single-family housing must have a fair interest rate not exceeding 40 basis points above the required net yield for a 60-day commitment to purchase a prime conventional conforming fixed rate mortgage. Loan-to-value ratio restrictions are not applicable, and prepayment penalties must be waived for refinanced qualified mortgages. The mortgage must have a term to maturity of not more than 40 years from the date of the beginning of the amortization, with waived prepayment penalties and no loan-to-value ratio restrictions. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation will refinance qualified mortgages on single-family housing with a term to maturity of not more than 40 years, waived penalties, and no loan-to-value ratio restrictions. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation will refinance qualified mortgages on single-family housing through a program established by the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency. The program established by the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency requires the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation to purchase or guarantee refinancing mortgages for qualified mortgages, without charging any up-front fees. The program established by the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency requires the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation to refinance qualified mortgages upon request without charging any up-front fees beyond the standard guarantee fee. Additionally, for second liens on qualified mortgages, refusal to resubordinate the lien may prevent refinancing. The program requires refinancing of qualified mortgages without additional fees. Second lien holders must resubordinate their liens for refinancing eligibility. The refinance requirement does not apply after a year. The program requires refinancing of qualified mortgages without additional fees. Second lien holders must resubordinate their liens for refinancing eligibility. The requirement for an enterprise to refinance qualified mortgages shall not apply after a 1-year period from the enactment of the Act, but the Director may extend the program in 1-year increments. The Director may extend the program established under this section in 1-year increments, and regulations will be issued as necessary. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation must ensure that mortgage servicers inform borrowers about the refinancing program. The Director will include updates on the program in the monthly Foreclosure Prevention & Refinance Report.
